STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 25, 2025
Jaclyn Caroffino
Jackson County DHHS
301 E LOUIS GLICK HWY,
JACKSON, MI, 49201-1535
Re: License #: CP380201203
SI #: 2025SIC0000458
Dear Ms. Caroffino:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000458
Special Investigation Intake Date: March 11, 2025
License #: CP380201203
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling
Chief Administrator: Jaclyn Caroffino
Agency Name: Jackson County DHHS
Agency Address: 301 E LOUIS GLICK HWY
JACKSON, MI 49201-1535
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/30/2027
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
4/1/2025 2:55 PM Phone Interview
3/26/2025 9:55 AM Phone Interview
3/17/2025 10:09 AM Phone Interview
3/14/2025 3:39 PM Phone Other
3/12/2025 4:40 PM Email Documentation received or sent
3/12/2025 4:17 PM Email Documentation received or sent
3/12/2025 2:19 PM Email Documentation received or sent
3/12/2025 2:09 PM Email Documentation received or sent

3/12/2025 1:32 PM Phone Special Evaluation Initiated Interview
3/12/2025 2:49 PM Email Documentation received or sent

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
Section (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
Description shall complete a written report that includes all of the following
information:
(e) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not recommend to the department the appropriate
licensing action consistent with facts contained in the foster
home's special evaluation.
Investigation Interviews:
On 3/12/2025 I spoke with the Complainant about the allegation.
Complainant reported the agency’s special evaluation outcome
should have resulted in noncompliance based on the special
evaluation narrative information, but it did not. Complainant
reported that the worker indicated no additional findings.
Complainant indicated the inappropriate findings related to rules
was noticed by the DCWL (Division of Child Welfare Licensing)
when a placement exception request, from the agency was being
reviewed by DCWL. Complainant had nothing further to add
related to the allegation.
On 3/12/2025 I had an email correspondence with the Chief
Administrator (CA) about the complaint allegation. CA directed
me to the Foster Care Program Manager to speak with about this
matter.
On 3/17/2025 I interviewed Foster Care Program Manager
(FCPM) by telephone. FCPM reported that the agency does not
get foster parent complaints very often. She reported she does
not sign off or have involvement related to the special evaluation
unless it was a very unusual situation. FCPM did not report this
foster parent’s special evaluation falling into that unusual situation
category. She reported having no concerns with how Licensing
Worker (LW) and Licensing Supervisor (LS) go about completing
special evaluations. She had no concerns about how LW and LS
completed the special evaluation for Foster Parent 1 and Foster
Parent 2 or their findings.
On 3/26/2025 I interviewed the Licensing Supervisor (LS) by
telephone. LS reported this complaint allegation against the
agency only came out because the agency asked for a placement
exception to be able to place another child in Foster Parent 1’s
2

and Foster Parent 2’s foster home; after Youth A went AWOL from
home and refused to return. LS reported the special evaluation
investigation on this foster home was conducted with Michigan
Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and Law
Enforcement (LE). LS reported DHHS had no findings and LE
denied things reported by Youth A. She reported Youth A was the
only person interviewed whose story changed related to the
reported allegations. LS reported Youth A had stated he was
going to say and do anything he could to get removed from Foster
Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s home. LS reported the foster
parents had done everything they could to care for Youth A. She
reported though it was true Foster Parent 1 threw the camera item
mentioned in the complaint; Foster Parent 1 threw the camera in
frustration. Foster Parent 1 did not intentionally throw the camera
at Youth A. She reported based on their investigation; the agency
did not assess that a foster home licensing rule violation was
warranted. She reported, since some training for foster parents
had come up in discussion with the licensing worker, the agency
suggested Trauma and Community Reintegration training for the
foster parents. She reported these training were suggestions not
mentioned as a requirement or mandate.
I interviewed Licensing Worker(LW) by telephone on 4/1/2025.
LW reported the special evaluation on the foster home was
conducted quite some time ago, June or July of last year; and she
stands by her findings. She reported she interviewed everyone,
and everyone’s stories matched except Youth A’s. Youth A’s
account of what happened was the only one that was inconsistent
and kept changing. LW reported a statement similarly to LS’s
related to what Foster Parent 1 did with respect to the camera,
that the foster parent threw the camera on the ground in
frustration. The foster parent did not throw the camera at Youth A.
LW reported “those cameras are expense”; and that “there is no
rule violation for frustration”. LW reported what happened during
the incident did not rise to the level of a citation for inappropriate
discipline and no non-compliance was indicated.
Document Reviewed:
The agency Special Evaluation report for Foster Parent 1 and
Foster Parent 2 completed by LW on 7/26/2024 and signed by LS
on 7/29/2024. The report indicated the following related to the
allegations, persons interviewed as it related to the allegations:
• On 6/24/2024 at 10:40 PM law enforcement was called to
the home regarding a physical assault between Foster
Parent 1 and Youth A. The foster parent and youth argued
3

about a camera that was placed directly outside Youth A’s
room. Youth A unplugged the camera and placed it into the
sump pump. When Foster Parent 1 looked for the camera
he was unable to find it. He asked Youth A about it and
Youth A retrieved it and gave the damaged camera to
Foster Parent 1. Foster Parent 1 threw the camera at Youth
A striking him in the groin. Youth A then shoved Foster
Parent 1 into a door causing a red mark to Foster Parent
1’s hand; and Foster Parent 1 called the police. Youth A
was not injured and there was no arrest.
• Foster Parent 1 admitted to throwing the camera. Foster
Parent reported the cameras are expensive, that this was
the third or fourth camera that Youth A had destroyed, and
so in frustration he threw the camera, and the camera
made contact with Youth A. Foster Parent 1 was unsure
whether the camera hit the ground before hitting Youth A or
just hit Youth A. Foster Parent reported Youth A then
pushed him into the doorframe of the basement causing
him to receive a cut to his hand. Foster Parent 1 reported
Youth B was the only youth to witness the incident that
occurred; because Youth C and Youth D were in their
room; and Youth E was asleep.
• Youth C, and Youth D did not witness the incident; and
Youth F could not be interviewed due to his age.
• Youth A reported not liking his home and wanting to leave,
wanting to go live with his biological grandmother and
sister. Youth A reported believing Foster Parent 1 had been
placing cameras facing his room and so he confronted him.
Youth alleged Foster Parent 1 got in his face and balled his
fist up. Youth A admitted to unplug the cameras in the past;
and in this instance putting the camera in water so it would
not work. Youth A reported he did not mean to throw the
camera in the water; it just went in. He reported
immediately afterwards, he grabbed the camera and gave
the camera to Foster Parent 1. He reported Foster Parent 1
threw the camera at him; it hit him in the groin area; and he
pushed Foster Parent 1. He reported Youth B was there,
witnessed the incident, and Foster Parent 1 called the
police. Youth A also alleged in this interview that Foster
Parent 1 had gotten in his face, and punched him in the
past, and that when he has hit Foster Parent 1 back, Foster
Parent 1 calls the police.
• Foster Parent 2 reported he was in the shower at the time
of the incident. Foster Parent 2 stated Youth B told him
Youth A hit Foster Parent 1, and he told Youth B to call
911. Foster Parent 2 said Foster Parent 1 told him Foster
4

Parent 1 threw the camera and thought the camera hit the
ground and then hit Youth A. Foster Parent 2 reported
when Youth A escalates the family calls 911. Foster Parent
2 reported Youth A did not tell him he was injured from the
event.
• Youth B reported Youth A came out of a room in the
basement holding a wet camera. Youth A handed the
camera to Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 1 threw the
camera. The camera hit Youth A on his upper thigh/genitals
and then bounced onto the floor. Youth A then pushed
Foster Parent 1 into the door and the police were called.
Youth B reported he was there and witnessed the event.
DHHS’s investigative report with respect to the event
allegations:
• The outcome of the DHHS interviews with Foster Parent
1, Foster Parent 2, Youth A, Youth B, Youth C.
• Youth C, and Youth D did not witness the incident.
• Foster Parent 1’s, Foster Parent 2’s, Youth A’s (aside
from some profanity language by him), and Youth B’s
interview statement was similar to the information
indicated in the agency’s special evaluation report.
• Youth E was not interviewed.
• Law Enforcement interviews with Foster Parent 1, Youth
A, Youth B and Youth C which showed each person’s
interview statement about the event allegation to be
similar to what was reported in this DHHS investigative
report and the agency’s special evaluation report.
• No disciplinary findings.
Analysis Based on interviews and document review, the evidence showed
during an event dispute with the adopted youth over camera use/
placement/displacement or destruction, Foster Parent 1,
notwithstanding any frustration on his part, threw a camera which
caused that camera to hit the adopted youth.
The special evaluation report showed that aforementioned
information, a rule citation to the foster home was warranted but
not indicated in the special evaluation. The licensing action was
not consistent with facts contained in the special evaluation and
on this evidence, the agency is found in noncompliance for this
rule.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
5

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current license status is recommended.
April 24, 2025
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 25, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
6

sir_summary.summary: The investigation found that Jackson County DHHS failed to properly evaluate a foster home incident where a foster parent threw a camera that struck an adopted youth during a dispute, leading to a physical altercation. The agency's special evaluation report documented the facts, including the foster parent admitting to throwing the camera, but incorrectly concluded no licensing rule violation had occurred, despite the evidence warranting a citation. The agency is held culpable for noncompliance due to its failure to recommend appropriate licensing action consistent with the documented facts.
